                         :       . .. 51.    Remarks^             ...    ’


                                                     Plans (one set only) to be submitted, and (if approved) to be retained by the Corporation.
                                                    : In addition to this notice, complete detailed plans of and sections through every floor of intended new building are required,
                                                  to be drawn in ink on tracing cloth to a scale of not less than one inch to every eight feet, and properly coloured or otherwise
                                                  suitably defined; and such plans shall show the position, form, and dimensions of the several parts of such building, the descrip­
                                                  tion of the rooms, and generally the position of every water closet, drain inlet, and all other appurtenances.
                                                     A block plan must also be sent, which shall be sufficient to identify the site, and show the position of the building and
                                                   IptM^enance^Ltbe-pmperties immediately, adjoining, the width and level of the street or ground in’ front, and of the street
                                                     any)^a^the?rea^of. the tbuilding, :the?level of the low est floor, of the,building,’and'of^any yard oF"op¥n^space“belonging thereto.'
                                                     A copy of the Bye-laws can be obtained at the office of the Building Surveyor. Town Hall.-                                       ___________1

                                                  : to prevent'the: Committee requiring further information in any case they may see fit.

                                              v              ..   B Y E -L A W S AS                  TO T H E             W O R K A N D C O M P L E T IO N . OF       NEW   B U IL D IN G S.         '
                                              rt; V A commencement?notice’must be sent to the Building Surveyor before any work in connection with new buildings is
                                               ' proceeded with..                                                              : ;.          •          .
                                              '      No ground intended for a. foundation, nor any damp course or drain shall be covered up without having been inspected and
                                            , ,    passed by the Council or their Building Surveyor, and all persons shall, after the foundation is excavated, or the damp course
                                                   or drains laid, give to the Council or their, Building Surveyor, three days’ notice specifying the date on which the foundations,
                                                  -damp course, or drains, will be covered up.                                            . ;; ;       .      ;    .

                                                                                                     f»
                                         NOTES FOR OUTDANCE IN COMPLETING THE APPLICATION
(A) An Industrial Development Certificate (issued by the Board of Trade) m ust accompany an application for permission for v.                        FORM No. 431
      relating to a building (i.e., its erection, extension, alteration or re-ereotion or a change of use of the whole or a port of it) if the d e v e K ^ y g . « . . .
      in question would create industrial floor space whioh, together with any other industrial floor space created or to be created by any ou*-*»*'W
      development (relating to the same building or another building in the same group of contiguous or adjacent buildings used as parts of a
      single undertaking)
      (а) which has been carried out, Or
      (б) for which planning permission under P art I I I ofthe Town and Country Planning Act, 1947, or of the Town and Country Planning
              Act, 1982 has been given,
       after the 31st March, 1960, would exceed 5,000 square feet, bu t excluding
       (a) any floor space created by any development in respect of which an Industrial Development Certificate has been issued and
       (b) any floor space created or for the creation of which planning permission has been given before the issue of such Certificate.
       N.B.—An extension of an industrial building does not need a Board of Trade Certificate if the extension, taken by itself, would not be an
                 industrial building.
 (B) I f (he application relates to :—
             (i) construction of buildings tor use as a public convenience ;
            (ii) construction ot buildings or other operations, or use ot land, tor the disposal ot retuse or waste materials ;
           (iii) construction of buildings or other operations (other than the laying ot sewers, the construction ot septic tanks serving single dwelling-
                 houses, and works ancillary thereto) or use ot land, tor the purpose ot sewage disposal;
           (iv) construction of buildings or use of land for the purposes of a slaughter house or knacker’s yard ;
            (v) construction of buildings and use of buildings tor any of the following purposes namely, as          a theatre, a           elnema, a musio hall,a dance
                 hall, a skating rink, a swimming bath or gymnasium (not forming part of a school, college or university), a Turkish or other vapour
                 or foam-bath, or a building for Indoor games,
        the applicant must, In accordance with the provisions of Section 15 of the Town and Country Planning Aet, 1962, attach hereto a copy of a
        notice prescribed by the Town and Country Planning General Development Order, 1963, and certified by him or on his behalf as having been
        published on a specified date in a named local newspaper circulating In the locality In which the land to which the application relates Is
        situated. (Copies of the form of notice can be obtained at the office of the City Engineer and Planning Officer, Town Hall, Sheffield, 1).
  (C) A kitchen should be regarded as a habitable room if it is intended to be used as a living room as well as a kitchen, but not otherwise.
  (D) The floor area of a building should be taken as the sum of the roofed areas of the building a t each floor level, including all wall thicknesses,
        corridors, staircases and basements.
  (E) I f the application relates to the winning and working of surface or underground minerals, attach details to this application, stating :—
             (i) the type of minerals to be extracted ;
            (ii) the estimated quantity to be extracted yearly ;
           (iii) the method, direction and estimated rate of working ;
           (iv) how it is proposed to deal with overburden, and the proposals (if any) for the treatm ent of the land                      after extraction, and
            (v) in the case of surface working, the estiinated maximum depths of the excavations.
         In place of the site and layout plans detailed below, plans should be attached to the application on a soale appropriate to the development
  (normally 25 in.—1 mile), showing the land to which the application relates, together with any adjoining land in the same ownership ; the area,
 if any, already excavated ; the sites of existing and proposedbuildings, tips, and meansof access ; and any proposals for the planting or
 restoration of trees.
 (F)     I f the application relates to any other type of development to whioh the additional information required under P a rt I of this form or note (E)
       above do not apply, a brief explanation, with plans of the proposed development, should be attached to this application.
                                                   NOTES ON THE ACCOMPANYING PLANS
       One copy of the plans and drawings is required.
       Instead of the set of plans and drawings detailed below only one plan need be furnished in any case where for the purposes of the Local
Planning A uthority the proposed development can be sufficiently described by particulars, together with a site plan drawn in accordance with
Paragraph I below. (In case of doubt please consult the City Engineer’s Department).
       Plans should be drawn in ink or reproduced in a clear and intelligible manner on linen and should be signed on every sheet by the
applicant or by his agent, all duplicates being tru e copies of the original plan or set of plans.
I.   Site Plan.
      (1) A site plan should be attached to all applications except
           (a) an application relating to a site included in a layout plan for which permission has been granted by the Council, in which oase a
                 copy of this layout plan, showing the land to which the application relates coloured pink, will suffice, and
           (b) an application relating to the extension or alteration of a building in a built-up area for which the fu ll postal address is given in
                 the application form, and for which a block plan is supplied in accordance with Note JU below.
      (2) The site plan should be drawn on a scale appropriate to the development (e.g., 25 in.—1 mile), showing the land to which the
           application relates coloured pink, any adjoining land in the same ownership coloured blue, and sufficient details to readily identify the
           site in comparison with the Ordnance Survey Map of the same soale. The Council should be consulted in any cases of doubt as to which
           scale is appropriate.
II. Layout Plan.
      (3) A layout plan should be attached to all applications for permission for building development, except as in paragraph (4) below. The
          plan should be drawn to a scale of not less than 1 : 2500 and should show
           (а) the boundaries of the land to winch the application relates, and the existing and proposed layout thereof, including any proposed
                 division of the land into plots ;
           (б) the position of all existing and proposed buildings, roads, streets, and carriageways thereon (distinguishing existing from proposed),
                 indicating for proposed buildings the maximum height for each building which will not be exceeded, and the levels and widths of
               ~ any proposed roads and streets ;
            (c) the proposed use of each building and any land not built on ;
           (d) if the layout is for residential development, the maximum numberof habitable rooms whioh will not be exceeded j
           (e) if the layout is for commercial or industrial development, the maximum floorarea which will not be exceeded ;
           (/) approxim ate land surface contours a t 10 feet vertical intervals, unless the site is flat land, in which case this may be dispensed
                 w ith by the Council ;
            (g) the approximate lines of water supply pipes, and of drains, watercourses and sewers, giving sizes and gradients, with reference
                 to any existing services in the locality ;
            (h) the situation of the land in relation to the nearest public road ;
            (*) the position and width of all means of access to roads, distinguishing between existing, alteration to existing, and proposed access ;
           (j ) any trees or natural features and whether these are to be preserved or not.
      (4) The layout plan is intended to enable the Council to examine the layout of the proposed building development in relation to the layout
            (either existing or intended) of the land surrounding the site.
           I t may be dispensed with
            (a) where the proposed development is a single building on an isolated site, surrounded by undeveloped land, which will remain
                 undeveloped, and
           (b) where the layout of the site is completely determined by existing and adjoining development,
m . Block and Building Plans.
      (5) Block and Building Plans properly coloured should be attached to all applications for the ereotion, rebuilding or alteration of a building.
           The Block Plan should be drawn to a scale of not less than 1 in,— i l • 66 ft. and the Building Plans to a soale of not less than J in.—1 ft.,
           except for large buildings, where after consultation with the Council a scale of not less than        in.—1 ft. may be used.
      (6) Block Plans should show
           (а) the boundaries of the plot ;
           (б) the position of existing buildings on the applicant’s land and on adjoining sitee •
           (c) the position of the proposed buildings ;
           (d) position and width of existing and proposed means of access ;
           (e) existing and proposed drains, manholes, septic tanks, cesspools, sewers, watercourses, indicating the size, depth and inclination
                 of any drains and means of ventilation, and distinguishing in ail cases existing from proposed works ;
           ( /) the position of the site in relation to the nearest street junction.
      (7) Building Plans should show
           (а) the materials to be used ;
           (б) the colour of the external walls and roofs ;
           (c) a plan for the roof and for eaoh floor ;
           (d) sections of every storey, floor, roof and foundations of the building ;
           (e) elevations of all sides of the building excluding party walls ;
           ( /) the level of the ground floor, and of the site in relation to the level of the adjoining street or streets;
           (g) the type of fuel binning apparatus (if any), to be installed, and
           (h) if applicable, the arrangements for the loading and unloading and parking of vehicles.

     Dear Inspector Pulford,

                            Sheffield Wednesday Football Club Ltd
                                    North^Wes^Corner         ^ .


                Your Mr* Grey has rung this office on one
      or two queries regarding the above and we came to
      an agreement as followsi-

      1*               We do think three exits are sufficient
                       to get a crowd into the street and each
                       one will be 6 ft* wide without centre
                       rails*   This would be adequate on the
                       basis that you have already agreed the
                       equivalent arrangement for the West
                       Stand*

      2   .                Height of the wall at the rear of Stage
                           II would be not less that 8 ft* It will
                           not now be a mesh fence in any case*
                           The parapet at the front would be not
                           less than U- ft* high.  It would not
                           necessarily be constructed entirely in
                           concrete, the probable arrangement
                           would be concrete raised to the required
                           height by a top rail to match the West
                           Stand arrangement at the bottom of isles*


                                        Yours sincerely,

                                                                                                      2
                                              NOTES FOR GUIDANCE IN COMPLETING THE APPLICATION
(A) An Industrial Development Certificate (issued by the Board of Trade) must accompany an application for permission for development
     relating to a building (i.e., its erection, extension, alteration or re-erection or a change of use of the whole or a part of it) if the development
     in question would create industrial floor space which, together with any other industrial floor space created or to be created by any other
     development (relating to the same building or another building in the same group of contiguous or adjacent buildings used as parts of a
     single undertaking)
     (а) which has been carried out, or                                                                 ; .;    . , |
     (б) for which planning permission under P art H I of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1947, or of the Town and Country Planning
            Act, 1962 has been given,                                        ,
     after the 31st March, 1960, would exceed 5,000 square feet, b ut excluding                                         >.    ,;
     (а) any floor space created by any development in respect of which an Industrial Development Certificate has been issued and
     (б) any floor space created or for the creation of which planning permission has been given before the issue of such Certificate.
     N.B.—An extension of an industrial building does not need a Board of Trade Certificate if the extendon, taken by itself, would not be an
               industrial building.                                                                                                                 ,
(B) I f the application relates to:—                                                                                       ,
           (i) construction of buildings for use as a public convenience;
          (ii) construction of buildings or other operations, or use of land, for the disposal ol refuse or waste materials;
         (iii) construction of buildings or other operations (other than the laying of sewers, the construction of septic tanks serving single dwelling-
               houses, and works ancillary thereto) or use of land, for the purpose of sewage disposal;
        (iv) construction of buildings or use of land for the purposes of a slaughter house or knacker’s yard;                                    ,        <:
          (v) construction of buildings and use of buildings for any of the following purposes namely, as a theatre, a cinema, a muslo hall, a dance
               hall, a skating rink, a swimming bath or gymnasium (not forming part of a school, college or university), a Turkish or other vapour
               or foam-bath, or a building for indoor games,
     the applicant must, in accordance with the provisions of Section 15 of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1962, attach hereto a copy of a
     notice prescribed by the Town and Country Planning General Development Order, 1963, and certified by him or on his behalf as having been
     published on a specified date in a named local newspaper circulating in the locality in which the land to which the application relates is
     situated. (Copies of the form of notice can be obtained at the office of the City Engineer and Planning Officer, Town Hall, Sheffield, 1).
(C) A kitchen should be regarded as a habitable room if it is intended to be used as a living room as well as a kitchen, but not otherwise.
(D) The floor area of a building should be taken as the sum of the roofed areas of the building at each floor level, including all wall thicknesses,
    corridors, staircases and basements.
(E) I f the application relates to the winning and working of surface or underground minerals, attach details to this application, stating:—
           (i) the type of minerals to be extracted;                                                                  '
          (ii) the estimated qflantity to be extracted yearly;
         (iii) the method, direction and estimated rate of working;                                                                   '
         (iv) how it is proposed to deal with overburden, and the proposals (if any) for the treatm ent of the land after extraction, and                    ' ;
          (v) in the case of surface working, the estimated maximum depths of the excavations.                                                          -M■■■'
        In place of the site and layout plans detailed below, plans should be attached to the application on a scale appropriate to the development ■
(normally 25 in. 1 mile), showing the land to which the application relates, together with any adjoining land in the same ownership; the area,
if any, already excavated; the sites of existing and proposed buildings, tips, and means of access; and any proposals for the planting or
restoration of trees.
(F) I f the application relates to any other type of development to which the additional information required under P art I of this form or note (E)
     a b o v e d o not a p p l y , a brief explanation, with plans of the proposed development, should be attaohed to this application.        i,,,j , , ,


                                                     NOTES ON THE ACCOMPANYING PLANS
            One copy of the plans and drawings is required.
            Plans should be drawn in ink or reproduced in a clear and intelligible manner on suitable durable material and should be signed on
     every sheet by the applicant or by his agent.
            Instead of the set of plans and drawings detailed below only one plan need be furnished in any case where for the purposes of the Local
     Planning Authority the proposed development can be sufficiently described by particulars, together with a site plan drawn in accordance with
     Paragraph I below. (In case of doubt please consult the City Engineer’s Department).
I,   Site Plan                                                                                  ; t.
     (1) A site plan should be attached to all applications except
          (а) an application relating to a site included in a layout plan for which permission has been granted by the Council, in which' case
                a copy of this layout plan, showing the land to which the application relates coloured pink, will suffice, and             "
          (б) an application relating to the extension or alteration of a building in a built-up area for which the/uK postal address is given in
                the application form, and for which a block plan is supplied in.accordance with Note H I below.
     (2) The site plan should be drawn on a scale appropriate to the development (e.g., 25 in.—1 mile), showing the land to which the
          application relates coloured pink, any adjoining land in the same ownership coloured blue, and sufficient details to readily identify the
          site in comparison with the Ordnance Survey Map of the same scale. The Council should be consulted in any oases of doubt as to which
          scale is appropriate.
I I. Layout Plan
     (3) A layout plan should be attaohed to all applications for permission for building development, except as in paragraph (4) below. The
          plan should be drawn to a scale of not less than 1 : 2500 and should show
          (а) the boundaries of the land to which the application relates, and the existing and proposed layout thereof, including any proposed
                division of the land into plots;
          (б) the position of all existing and proposed buildings, roads, streets, and carriageways thereon (distinguishing existing from proposed),
                indicating for proposed buildings the maximum height for each building which will not be exceeded, and the levels and widths of.
                any proposed roads and streets;
          (c) the proposed use of each building and any land not built on;                                                                      .;.
          (d) if the layout is for residential development, the maximum number of habitable rooms which will not be exceeded;
          (e) if the layout is for commercial or industrial development, the maximum floor area which will not be exceeded; .                   .
          ( /) approximate land surface contours a t 10 feet vertical intervals, unless the site is flat land, in which case this m ay be dispensed
               with by the Council;
          (g) the approximate lines of water supply pipes, and of drains, watercourses and sewers, giving sizes and gradients, with reference:
                to any existing services in the locality;
          (h) the situation of the land in relation to the nearest public road; _                 _ _              ‘           ^
          (i) the position and width of all means of access to roads, distinguishing between existing, alteration to         existing, and proposed aooess;
          (j) any trees or natural features and whether these are to be preserved or not.
     (4) The layout plan is intended to enable the Council to examine the layout of the proposed building development in relation to the layout
          (either existing or intended) of the land surrounding the site.
          I t may be dispensed with
          (a) where the proposed development is a single building on an isolated site;, surrounded by undeveloped land, which will remain
                undeveloped, and                                                                                  i
          (b) w h e r e the layout of the site is completely determined by existing and adjoining development.                      *'        1 1 >
H I. Block and Building Plans                                                                                           .          .i
     (5) Block and Building Plans should be attached to all applications for the erection, rebuilding or alteration of a building. The Block
          Plan snould be drawn to a scale of not less than 1 : 1250 and the Building Plans to a scale of                        not less then Jin.—I ft,,
         except for large buildings, where after consultation with the Council a scale of not less than -&in.—1 ft.             may be used.
     (6) Block Plans should show
         (а) the boundaries of the plot;                                                                                                 .........
          (б) the position of existing buildings on the applicant’s land and on adjoining sites;
          (c) the position of the proposed buildings;
          (d) position and width of existing and proposed means of access;
          le) existing and proposed drains, manholes, septic tanks, cesspools, sewers, watercourses, indicating the size, depth and inclination
                of any drains and means of ventilation, and distinguishing in all cases existing from proposed works;
          ( /) the position of the site in relation to the nearaBt street junction.                                          ic : . i . . >, •
     (7) Building Plans should show
          (а) the materials to be used;
          (б) the colour of external walls and roofs;                                                                                            .. .
          (c) a plan for the roof and for each floor;
          (d) sections of every storey, floor, roof and foundations of the building;                           .........
          (e) elevations of all sides of the building excluding party walls;
          ( / ) the level of the ground floor, and of the site in relation to the level o f the adjoining street or streets;
           (g) if applicable, the arrangements for the loading and unloading and parking of vehicles.                                               RS. 30

                                                                                                                             Depufy T o w n C                                                                                 le rk ;        ' - v ^*
     1. If the applicant is aggrieved by the decision of the Council to refuse permission or approval for the
proposed development, or to grant permission or approval subject to conditions, he may, by notice served within
one month of receipt of this notice, appeal to the Minister of Housing and Local Government in accordance with
Section 23 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1962. The appropriate form is obtainable from the Ministry
of Housing and Local Government, Whitehall, London, S.W .I. The Minister has power to allow a longer period
for the giving of a notice of appeal and lie will exercise his power in cases where he is satisfied th at the applicant
has deferred the giving of notice because negotiations with the Council in regard to the proposed development
are in progress. The Minister is not, however, required to entertain such an appeal ii it appears to him th a t
permission for the proposed development could not have been granted by the Council, or could not have been so
sranted otherwise than subject to the conditions imposed by them, having regard to the provisions of the develop-;
merit orders, and to any directions given under the orders.                                                     ■' •
     If the applicant decides to appeal to the Minister of Housing, and Local Government and the Council's
decision is based either wholly or partly on advice from a Government Department and this advice is included in
the Council’s decision, a representative from th a t Department will attend any inquiry held by the Minister and
be available to give evidence if the applicant has, not later than fourteen days before the date of the inquiry
applied in writing to the Minister for such a representative to be made available a t th e inquiry. Such a repre­
sentative would not be liable to cross-examination on questions of Ministerial policy .but only on m atters of fact
and expert opinion.                                              ,
     2. If permission to develop land is refused, or granted subject to conditions, whether by the' Council or
by the Minister of Housing and Local Government and the owner of th e land claims th a t the land has become
incapable of reasonably beneficial use in its existing state and cannot be rendered capable of reasonably benefiqial
use by the carrying out of any development which has been or would be permitted, he may. serve on the Council
a purchase notice requiring the Council.to purchase his interest in the land in accordance w ith’the provisions
of P art V III of the Town and Country Planning Act 1992.                              •>                  J ^
    ' 3 .' In certain circumstances, a claim may be made against the Council for compensation, where permission
is refused or granted subject to conditions by the Minister on appeal or on a reference of .the application to
him. The circumstances in which such compensation is payable are set out in Section 123 of the Town and
Country Planning Act 1962.-                                                                          '‘    ■I".
      4. This planning permission is granted under the above-mentioned Act an d orders only and does .. not
•constitute a permission, approval or consent by the Council for any other purpose whatsoever. Application m ost
 therefore be made tq the appropriate D epartm ent of the Corporation for any other permission, approval or
 consent (including approval under the Building Regulations or Building Byelaws, as th e case may be) w hichm ay
 be necessary in connection with the proposed development or anything incidental thereto, or th e use to be made
 of the premises which form the subject of such development.                              r;              <i:; '

                                                                                                                                           2
                                         NOTES FOR GUIDANCE IN COMPLETING THE APPLICATION
(A) An Industrial Development Certificate (issued by the Board of Trade) must accompany an application for permission for developme
     relating to a building (i.e., its erection, extension, alteration or re-erection or a change of use of the whole or a p art of it) if the development
     in question would create industrial floor space which, together with any other industrial floor space created or to be created by any other
     development (relating to the same building or another building in the same group of contiguous or adjacent buildings used as parts of a
     single undertaking)
     (а) which has been carried out, or
     (б) for which planning permission under P art I I I of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1947, or of the Town and Country Planning
            Act, 1962 has been given,
     after the 31st March, 1960, would exceed 5,000 square feet, but excluding
     (0) any floor space created by any development in respect of which an Industrial Development Certificate h&3 been, issued and
     (6) any floor space created or for the creation of which planning permission has been given before the issue of such Certificate,
     N.B.—An extension of an industrial building does not need a Board of Trade Certificate if the extension, taken by itself, would not be an
               industrial building.
(B) I f the application relates to:—
           (i) construction of buildings (or use as a public convenience;
         (ii) construction of buildings or other operations, or use of land, for the disposal of refuse or waste materials;
        (iii) construction of buildings or other operations (other than the laying of sewers, the construction of septic tanks serving single dwelling*
               houses, and works ancillary thereto) or use of land, for the purpose of sewage disposal;
        (iv) construction of buildings or use of land for the purposes of a slaughter house or knacker’s yard;
         (v) construction of buildings and use ot buildings tor any of the following purposes namely, as a theatre, a cinema, a music hall, a dance
               hall, a skating rink, a swimming bath or gymnasium (not forming part of a school, college or university), a Turkish or other vapour
               or foam-bath, or a building for Indoor games,
     the applicant must, in accordance with the provisions of Section 15 of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1962, attach hereto a cop; of a
     notice prescribed by the Town and Country Planning General Development Order, 1963, and certified by him or on his behalf as having been
     published on a specified date In a named local newspaper circulating'ln the locality In which the land to which the application relates Is
     situated. (Copies of the form of notice can be obtained at the office of the City Engineer and Planning Officer, Town Hail, Sheffield, 1).
(C) A kitchen should be regarded as a habitable room if it is intended to be used as a living room as well as a kitchen, but not otherwise.
(D) The floor area of a building should be taken as the sum of the roofed areas of the building a t each floor level, including all wall thicknesses,1
     corridors, staircases and basements.
(E) I f the application relates to the winning and working of surface or underground minerals, attach details to this application, stating:—
          (i) the type of minerals to be extracted;
         (ii) the estimated quantity to be extracted yearly;
        (iii) the method, direction and estimated rate of working;
        (iv) how it is proposed to deal with overburden, and the proposals (if any) for the treatm ent of the land after extraction, and
         (v) in the case of surface working, the estimated maximum depths of the excavations.
        In place of the site and layout plans detailed below, plans should be attached to the application on a soale appropriate to the development
(normally 25 in.— 1 mile), showing the land to which the application relates, together with any adjoining land in the same ownership; the area,
if any, already excavated; the sites of existing and proposed buildings, tips, and means of access; and any proposals for the planting or
restoration of trees.
(F) I f the application relates to any other type of development to which the additional information required under P art I of this form or note (E)
     above do not apply, a brief explanation, with plans of the proposed development, should be attached to this application.
                                                        NOTES ON THE ACCOMPANYING PLANS
           One copy of the plans and drawings is required.
           Plans should be drawn in ink or reproduced in a clear and intelligible manner on suitable durable material and should be signed on
   every sheet by the applicant or by his agent.
           Instead of the set of plans and drawings detailed below only one plan need be furnished in any case where for the purposes of the Local
   Planning Authority the proposed development can be sufficiently described by particulars, together with a site plan drawn in accordance with
   Paragraph I below. (In case of doubt please consult the City Engineer’s Department).
I. iSite Plan
      (1) A site plan should be attached to all applications exoept
            (а) an application relating to a site included in a layout plan for which permission has been granted by the Council, in which case
                   a copy of this layout plan, showing the land to which the application relates coloured pink, will suffice, and
            (б) an application relating to the extension or alteration of a building in a built-up area for which the full postal address is given in
                   the application forp, and for which a block plan is supplied in accordance with Note I I I below.
      (2) The site plan should be drawn on a scale appropriate to the development (e.g., 25 in.—1 mile), showing the land to which the
           application relates coloured pink, any adjoining land in the same ownership coloured blue, and sufficient details to readily identify the
           site in comparison with the Ordnance Survey Map of the same scale. The Council should be consulted in any oases of doubt as to which
           scale is appropriate.
II. Layout Plan
      (3) A layout plan should be attached to all applications for permission for building development, exoept as in paragraph (4) below. The
           plan should be drawn to a scale of not less than 1 : 2500 and should show
           (а) the boundaries of the land to which the application relates, and the existing and proposed layout thereof, including any proposed
                  division of the land into plots;
           (б) the position of all existing and proposed buildings, roads, streets, and carriageways thereon (distinguishing existing from proposed),
                  indicating for proposed Iniildings the maximum height for each building which will not be exceeded, and the levels and widths of
                  any proposed roads and streets;
           (c) the proposed use of each building and any land not built on;
            (d) if the layout is for residential development, the maximum number of habitable rooms which will not be exceeded;
            (e) if the layout is for commercial or industrial development, the maximum floor area which will not be exceeded;
            ( /) approximate land surface contours a t 10 feet vertical intervals, unless the site is flat land, in which case this may be dispensed
                  with by the Counoil;
            (g) the approximate lines of water supply pipes, and of drains, watercourses and sewers, giving sizes and gradients, with reference
                  to any existing services in the locality;
            (h) the situation of the land in relation to the nearest public road;
            (i) the position and width of all means of access to roads, distinguishing between existing, alteration to existing, and proposed access;
           (j) any trees or natural features and whether these are to be preserved or not.
      (4) The layout plan is intended to enable the Council to examine the layout of the proposed building development in relation to the layout
           (either existing or intended) of the land surrounding the site.
           I t may be dispensed with
           (а) where the proposed development is a single building on an isolated site, surrounded by undeveloped land, which will remain
                  undeveloped, and
           (б) where the layout of the site is completely determined by existing and adjoining development.
 III. Block and Building Plans
       (5) Block and Building Plans should be attached to all applications for the erection, rebuilding or alteration of a building. The Block
            Plan snould be drawn to a scale of not less than 1 : 1250 and the Building Plans to a scale of not less then Jin.—1 ft.,
            except for large buildings, where after consultation with the Council a scale of not less than -jjrin,—1 ft. may be used.
      (6) Block Plans should show
           (a) the boundaries of the plot;
           (b) the position of existing buildings on the applicant’s land and on adjoiningsites;
           (c) the position of the proposed buildings;
           (d) position and width of existing and proposed means of access;
            le) existing and proposed drains, manholes, septic tanks, cesspools, sewers,watercourses, indicating the size, depth and inclination
                  of any drains and means of ventilation, and distinguishing in all oases existing from proposed works;
            i f ) the position of the site in relation to the nearest street junction.
      (7) Building Plans should show
            (a) the materials to be used;
            (b) the colour of external walls and roofs;
            (c) a plan for the roof and for each floor;
            (d) sections of every storey, floor, roof and foundations of the building;
            (e) elevations of all sides of the building excluding party walls;
            ( /) the level of the ground floor, and of the site in relation to the level of the adjoining street or streets;
             (g) if applicable, the arrangements for the loading and unloading and parking of vehicles.                                     RS. 30
